<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of cleanup_upgraded_connection:
```c
static void
cleanup_upgraded_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = connection->urh;

  if (NULL == urh)
    return;
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  /* Signal remote client the end of TLS connection by
   * gracefully closing TLS session. */
  if (0 != (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))
    gnutls_bye (connection->tls_session,
                GNUTLS_SHUT_WR);

  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != urh->mhd.socket)
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (urh->mhd.socket);

  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET != urh->app.socket)
    MHD_socket_close_chk_ (urh->app.socket);
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
  connection->urh = NULL;
  free (urh);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function cleanup_upgraded_connection:
enum MHD_AuthType type
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (0 != (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))
    gnutls_bye (connection->tls_session,
                GNUTLS_SHUT_WR);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The pointer connection->tls_session is passed to gnutls_bye which operates on (and likely modifies) the session object; therefore the pointer must be to a non-const object. Rule 8.13 requires adding const only when the pointed-to object is not modified — that does not apply here. A violation would occur if the code passed or stored a pointer to an object that is never modified but whose type is not const-qualified (for example, using a non-const pointer to read-only data), but that is not the case in this fragment.
